subject: Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: Yes, my tool produces senior output. There s a tool in the files area to do TO to Junior but wiring in a different dictionary (eg Australian ) may not be
messageBody:
Yes, my tool produces senior output. There's a tool in the files
area to do TO to Junior but wiring in a different dictionary (eg
Australian ) may not be possible I dunno. I think there are some perl
converters too that might make switching dictionaries possible if perl
is your bent. In a pinch I suppose I can chop up my app to do junior
as well but please don't make me ;->. What I can *not* do is find an
Australian phonetic dictionary.

Ideally the sample of Australian would be made either by a native
speaker or a machine since our own biases could influence the result
profoundly.

Worth noting also is this: The 60 or so abbreviated forms and
standards for adding -ing and -ed etc make Senior differ less between
accents than Junior, possibly significantly, we'd have to compare. But
if so that's easy to address: use the Senior abbreviations and
standards for suffixes to spell Junior and just leave the letter
joining out.

(your difficult in reading it is likely *my* fault, the font I use has
been mercilessly butchered by me and the joining of letters is still
not right. I am, after all, still working on the tool itself)


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
> Anthony Grahn wrote:
> >
> >
> > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
> > <mailto:Read_Alphabet%40yahoogroups.com>, John Cowan <cowan@> wrote:
> >
> > >(There are also splits, where a lexical set divides into two
> > >different pronunciations, but QS just can't handle those at all.)
> >
> > True, QS with the wrong implementation cannot. But QS treated
> > phonemically can: I do not believe there has ever been a QS user who
> > tried to find a letter for a sound and failed. The problem has been
> > the reverse: we find too many letters that work. There are two
> > proposals now to solve this:
> > 1. do not use letters for sounds not found in your accent.
> > 2. follow a complex set of rules to simulate Upper Class British
> > English.
> > My bias is towards number 1.
> >
> > >> it is just one letter out of 6 in one word out of 50 and is
> > unimportant.
> > >Au contraire. Hundreds of thousands of words are affected.
> >
> > I'm sure you have a basis for this figure even though it so very
> > strongly resembles a complete guess. It would perhaps be better to
> > show us an Australian and Non-Australian version of the same text side
> > by side as I have done with US vs RP here:
>
> > http://quickscript.tonygrahn.com/spellcomparison.html
>
> This comparison is in senior QS, right? I have a hard time reading
it. I
> too would like to see concrete examples at this point. I have tried to
> see what QS might look like if written phonetically for the Australian
> dialect. (My understanding is that there are not letters for some of
the
> sounds in Australian English; but at least show this in a concrete
> example and try to approxtimate). But I can't find a really good
list of
> words.
>
> The words wouldn't have to be in QS; they could appear side by side
with
> their IPA transcriptions for each word.
>
> This is all I've been able to find so far:
>
> Australian "day" sounds like "die";
> Australian "buy" sounds like "boy".
>
